column2: as part of an "educational and familiarisation tour" to a number of universities and institutions in Qatar.

column1: QIIB chief executive officer Dr Abdulbasit Ahmed al-Shaibei met the Omani delegation along with members of the bank's executive management team.

column2: and stressed on the importance of exchanging educational visits and acquiring experiences in the field of banking.

column1: He said
column2: "The brotherly relations between Qataris and Omanis will help better interaction in various fields. There is no doubt that the role played by various institutions

column2: which is rapidly and consistently growing and has become one of the most important and most competitive economies in the world

column1: The role of QIIB goes beyond achieving profits as it seeks to support development. The bank contributes to the financing of various sectors and projects that provide added value to the society. column2: and similar visits from Al-Buraimi University students to the bank will be frequent
column3: which will benefit the students and the university and encourage the various institutions to initiate partnerships that serve all those concerned."

column2: during which various aspects of Islamic banking
column3: achievements and challenges at the global level
column4: confidence Islamic banking enjoys as a result of adopting ethical principles and relying on real transactions and assets
column5: away from consumer finance and quick profits
column6: were dealt with.

column1: Besides being profitable
column2: Islamic banks' focus on financing development
column3: which provides value addition to the society and promotes holistic development that serves the interest of the largest possible segment of the society.

This requires universities to keep pace with the expansion of this market in an appropriate manner.
At the end of the visit
column2: the Omani university delegation expressed their gratitude to QIIB for welcoming them and briefing them about its vast experience and expertise in Islamic banking
column3: which added qualitative value to their knowledge in this vital field. Gulf Times Newspaper 2020

The Philippines is keen to partner with Qatar in the development of the Southeast Asian country's Islamic banking system
column2: a ranking official of the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) said Sunday.

column1: Speaking on the sidelines of the four-day Doha leg of the DTI's 'Outbound Business Matching Mission (OBMM) to GCC 2020'
column2: DTI-Trade Promotions Group (TPG) undersecretary Abdulgani M Macatoman said the Philippines could benefit from Qatar's expertise in Islamic banking and Shariah-compliant policies.

column1: The Philippines has abundant opportunities for partnerships in many sectors, among which is Islamic banking, and we are looking forward to working with Qatar in this particular field, Macatoman told Gulf Times.
Macatoman is in Qatar to lead a trade delegation composed of representatives from 11 Philippine business companies participating in the DTI's OBMM initiative
column2: which concludes Monday. The OBMM was organised in collaboration with the Philippine Embassy in Qatar.

column1: The DTI undersecretary's delegation also includes Philippine commercial attache for the Middle East and Africa Charmaine Mignon S Yalong
column2: DTI-EMB senior trade and industry development Specialist Myrtle Faye L Solina
column3: and trade and industry development specialist Al-Mahdi I Jul-Ahmad.

column1: Part of our campaign is to encourage prospective Qatari investors to look at the possibility of venturing into the Islamic banking system in the Philippines, Macatoman continued
column2: adding that while in Qatar the Philippine delegation was able to speak to two potential partners in this field.

column1: The trade undersecretary also noted that following the suggestion of Philippine ambassador to Qatar Alan Timbayan
column2: talks are also in the pipeline to explore the possibility of putting up Shariah-compliant pawnshops in the Philippines
column3: citing the 2.3mn overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) who could benefit from the idea.

column1: Following the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas's (BSP) approval of initial regulations implementing Republic Act (RA) 11439 or the new Islamic Banking Law
column2: Macatoman stressed that many Filipinos will benefit from this
column3: particularly "the more than 10mn 'unbanked' Filipinos
column4: most of whom are from the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Mindanao.

column1: The BSP website states that in August 2019
column2: Philippine President Rodrigo R Duterte signed RA 11439 mandating the BSP to exercise regulatory powers and supervision over the operations of Islamic banks and to issue the implementing rules and regulations on Islamic banking.

column1: According to BSP governor Benjamin E Diokno
column2: "RA 11439 will unlock the full potential of Islamic financing in fostering inclusive economic growth. With a well-defined regulatory framework now in place
column3: the BSP looks forward to seeing greater participation in Islamic financing by both domestic and foreign banks."

column1: This is expected to widen opportunities for Muslim Filipinos, including those from the Bangsamoro Region, in accessing banking products and services. This is a great stride in our financial inclusion mandates, Diokno added. Gulf Times Newspaper 2020

Last week
column2: Shariah scholars from across Asean congregated in Singapore for the annual "Muzakarah Cendekiawan Shariah Nusantara" organised by the Malaysia-based International Shariah Research Academy for Islamic Finance.

column1: This wonderful annual event brings regional industry players
column2: Shariah scholars and regulators together to exchange views on the practical applications of Shariah in the Islamic financial market.

column1: I thought I should pay homage to the muzakarah in my column by discussing this year's talking points centred on fees and charges chargeable in Islamic finance. I will focus the discussion here on the most important issue that keeps every industry player awake at night
column2: which is the charging of an Islamic bank's financial costs to customers.

column1: Currently
column2: any cost that is considered to be financial in nature is not accepted as real or actual cost of the bank
column3: and therefore has not been allowed to be charged to customers by many learned Shariah experts.

column1: It has been said that financial cost in the form of the forced unwinding of hedging and funding arrangements arising from the early termination or default of a fixed rate financing is not an actual cost because many see it as an opportunity loss rather than an actual loss to the bank.

Many make the assumption that every non-consummated fixed rate Islamic financing contract is replaceable with an equivalent transaction immediately. Many say that the hedge is something that the bank has to do anyway as part of prudent business undertaking
column2: so it should not claim from customers. Many forget that the bank had to enter the hedging because the customers demanded an affordable fixed rate
column3: long-term Islamic financing. Without the hedging
column4: the cost of the financing to the customer would be more expensive.

column1: Worse
column2: many seem to have forgotten that Islamic banks do not give loans like conventional banks. An Islamic bank gives financing but it is done by way of a real trade contract. If the trade contract is unreal then it would not have attracted double stamp duty
column3: real property gains tax or other relevant tax to the extent that the Islamic bank requires tax neutrality be provided under law by the government in every tax jurisdiction.

column1: This blinked view of the situation caused many Islamic banks to absorb the losses suffered due to the inability to charge a break funding fee.
I guess this is the true problem statement. This makes Islamic banks totally inefficient and disadvantaged compared to conventional riba-based bank. Globally
column2: this is one reason why Islamic banks' return on equity is
column3: on average
column4: inferior to conventional banks' with a few exceptions like Al-Rajhi Bank in Saudi Arabia and CIMB Islamic Bank Bhd in Malaysia.

column1: Islamic banks are licensed to do banking business. Some Islamic banks in Asean do carry a universal banking licence but most are just licensed to do traditional regulated banking activities such as taking deposits and providing financing to customers.
Under such approved activities
column2: the full set of banking business requirements have to be fulfilled by Islamic banks for them to fulfill their obligations under the licence. Any intervention that interrupts this would be detrimental to Islamic banks and causes many to fail the fundamental objective to facilitate financial inclusion and effective distribution of wealth.

column1: Generally
column2: financial costs are real costs of the Islamic banks in doing their function as the mobilisers of funds. Real costs in Islamic banking business can be easily equated with the real costs under non-financial businesses. Although Islamic banking business is purportedly a financial business in nature
column3: it does carry the same financial costs as any normal trade that is non-financial in nature.

column1: An exporter of goods may enter into a hedging contract to mitigate the risk of the sale arising from currency risk
column2: funding risk and so on
column3: in the event of cancellation
column4: early payment or default of the sale contract and to provide best pricing for the buyer. They may also enter a specific funding arrangement just because of the specific purchase by the buyer.

column1: Based on fair trade practice and a willing buyer
column2: willing seller basis
column3: the exporter could charge a break fee to discourage or to incentivise the buyer not to cancel
column4: early pay or default the contract. There is no known Shariah reason to prohibit this
column5: even from an ethics' perspective.

column1: Financial costs such as break funding costs caused by the unwinding of risk management tool for the trade entered by an Islamic bank are similarly very real under banking business.
Without it
column2: customers will never get access to affordable financial solutions
column3: which is the hallmark of banking as a public good.

column1: We must always remember that Islamic banking with its two-part fund mobilisation system has long been approved as activities consistent with Shariah by many qualified Shariah scholars globally. As long as there is no contradiction with clear express prohibitions in the Quran and legitimate Hadith
column2: any activity under the Islamic banking practice that is a prerequisite business requirement
column3: should not be disallowed and continue to be disallowed.

column1: I believe one cannot invite someone for dinner and then say he can eat the food but cannot drink
column2: or worse
column3: he can chew the food but cannot swallow. Such invitation is incomplete. The same incompleteness exists when allowing a licensed Islamic bank to do Islamic banking business but not allowing it to charge the consequential financial cost it has to incur to make it affordable to the customers.

column1: Having said all of the above
column2: many would still have difficulty accepting the need to allow an Islamic bank to charge financial cost. However
column3: going back to basics
column4: what right does anyone have to deny a seller of goods (in this case Islamic banks) the ability to get the full selling price that has been contracted with the buyer (ie the bank's customer) if all conditions are met? The answer here is none. I would even go as far as saying it compromises the very basic principle of Muamalat. Of course this does not preclude the bank from giving rebate or discount.

column1: An Islamic bank has the absolute right to the full sale price of a trade contract so the discussion on break funding cost rightly is superfluous in the first instance. However
column2: we are forced to discuss it because people have accused Islamic banks of doing interest-based lending business.

column1: We should never lose the plot of what Islamic banking business is all about. People need to stop this misplaced accusation against Islamic banks when fundamentally it is not and cannot do so under Shariah.

A forced lifting of the veil in the underlying transactions to supposedly expose the purported characteristics of the Islamic banking instruments will only defeat the very purpose of the original application of Shariah principle to provide traditional banking services to principally alleviate poverty among the two billion Muslims globally. If murabahah transaction is stripped off from murabahah financing for example
column2: what is left is the outright lending with the charging of interest
column3: which is unlawful under Shariah.

column1: The net effect might be the same
column2: but financing or monetisation using proper Shariah trade structure is very different from conventional riba-based financing. The former
column3: which is trade
column4: is encouraged under Shariah
column5: while the latter
column6: which is riba
column7: is clearly prohibited.

column1: The confusion between the two is already foreseen in the Quran.
All in all
column2: Islamic banks undertake trade as approved banking activities under financial regulation allowing its customers to own
column3: say a house or a car on fixed term and deferred payment basis. Islamic banks do have flexi rate financing but the issue of financial cost charges is not relevant. The financial cost arising from any hedging or funding arrangement entered to allow an Islamic bank to sell a house or a car on an affordable
column4: fixed-term basis is typically built into the financial obligations of the customer under the underlying Shariah based contracts.

column1: I sincerely hope my hoopla here on the issue of chargeable fees and charges in Islamic finance helps elicit a deeper thought process and brings us back to the reality of the issue. There are many things that we do not know and not sure of but if we stay true to Shariah
column2: we will not lose sight of the ultimate objective of Shariah
column3: which is to bring benefit to all mankind and prevent them from harm.

column1: In the end
column2: not allowing the charges of financial cost within the sale price under a sales contract entered by an Islamic bank with a customer brings more harm to society than good.

column1: Just remember that Shariah has always given the right to the full sale price to a seller of goods to start with but some of us in the context of Islamic banking business seem adamant to change the rule of sale
column2: that has stood for millennia
column3: to the detriment of the Islamic finance industry.

column1: Against the backdrop of the importance of Small and Medium scale Enterprises (SMEs) to the growth of per capital income and the economy of any country as a whole
column2: the funding challenges faced by the sector
column3: especially with the seemingly prohibitive lending rate from conventional banks
column4: the issue of alternative and friendly funding have again returned to the front burner of discourse amongst economists and analysts alike.

column1: According to Director General
column2: Lagos Chamber of Commerce and Industry (LCCI) Alhaji Muda Yusuf
column3: "The SMEs sector contributes over 70 per cent of the jobs in the economy and yet enjoys less than 10 per cent of total credit in the financial system. This is critical issue that needs to be addressed if the economy must be inclusive
column4: he told THISDAY. THISDAY findings indicated that funding is a major problem for many small businesses. Most small business owners finance their businesses through personal savings, support from family and friends and suppliers credit. This challenge, findings revealed, is one of the major impediments to job creation in country.

column1: It will be recalled that the International Organisations of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) had among others stated that "Capital Markets therefore have a role in bridging this financing gap for SMEs by providing alternative funding sources
column2: Reacting to enquiries on capital markets as a source of access to fund by SMEs, Chief Executive Officer of Global Analytics Derivatives, Tope Fasua, had contended that the Nigeria Capital Market was not accustomed to providing financing for SMEs at the present and argued that this may be due to issues bordering on sharp practices on the part of some of the listed corporation and companies in the bourse.

column1: According to Fasua "At present
column2: our Capital Market is not very much attuned to helping SMEs raise money
column3: chiefly because we have issues with the big companies already listed and if we should concentrate on SMEs raising money at the stock exchange
column4: things could get pretty messy. There are strict rules
column5: and global best practices that must be adhered to for a company to raise money in the capital market. What we have seen is a situation where even the large companies cut corners
column6: present fake accounts
column7: and perpetrate a lot of schemes and scams that have reduced confidence in capital markets".

column1: This
column2: among other factors
column3: has caused industry watchers to look the way of Non-Interest banking more popular as Islamic banking as a possible route for accessing funds by SMEs. Proponents of this line of thought argued that besides that Islamic banking is open to Muslims and non-Muslims alike
column4: it presents a win-win situation for the borrower as it helps to shoulder the risks involved in the eventuality of loss. They also added that some SMEs may not be able to access funding from Islamic banking by virtue of the kinds of business they do.

column1: Background Islamic banking has the same purpose as conventional banking except that it operates in accordance with the rules of Sharia
column2: known as Fiqh al-Muamalat (Islamic rules on transactions). The basic principle of Islamic banking is the sharing of profit and loss and the prohibition of riba? (interest). Amongst the common Islamic concepts used in Islamic banking are profit sharing (Mudharabah)
column3: safekeeping (Wadiah)
column4: joint venture (Musharakah)
column5: cost plus (Murabahah)
column6: and leasing (Ijarah). However
column7: Islamic banking in Nigeria received the nod from the central bank in 2011 after several years of attempts by different groups and organizations. A framework
column8: released in the same year by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN)
column9: spelt out guidelines for the establishment
column11: Shari'ah governance and supervision of Islamic banks which can be standalone full-fledged institutions

column1: Both Jaiz Bank Plc and Stanbic IBTC were granted licenses to operate based as a full-fledged Islamic bank and window respectively in the same year and both began operations in 2012. Sterling Bank Plc joined the market in April 2013 as a window. THISDAY findings revealed that Jaiz bank
column2: which was licensed to operate as a regional bank
column3: is already eyeing a national license to enable it to penetrate the southern part of the country. The bank's balance sheet grew to about 36 billion naira as at the end of 2012 and its branch network increased from an initial three in 2011 to 14 as at May 2013 and 30 by June 2015. The other two operators that operate as Islamic windows offer Islamic banking products and services in all their branches nationwide. This has helped expand the reach to prospective clients even in the southern part of the country where the majority of the population are not Muslims.

column1: Islamic banking operators collectively provide several Shari'ah-compliant products and services to cater for the diverse needs of their clients. These include products based on murabaha
column2: mudaraba; musharaka
column3: ijara WA iqtina and kafala
column4: the products provided include current
column5: term deposit and savings accounts on the liability sides using qard
column6: wadiah and mudaraba contracts. Financing of automobiles
column7: household equipment
column8: housing
column9: and import financing have been the major focus of the Islamic banks
column11: ijara wa iqtina and istisna contracts.

column1: As part of efforts to extend its tentacles to the South-West of the country
column2: the South-West Zonal Committee for the operations of Jaiz Bank recently held a stakeholders forum in Ibadan
column3: Oyo State where it drummed up awareness for the concept of Islamic banking. Speaking at the forum
column4: an economist with specialization in banking operations
column5: Professor Abdul-Hakeem Mobolaji
column6: condemned what he described as exploitative interest rates charged by Nigerian banks and urged the apex bank to relax its regulations for Islamic banking to grow adding that "Islamic bank grows at an annual rate of 17.6 percent . The bank is not only for Muslims. In Britain
column7: 73 percent of those who patronize the bank are non-Muslims
column8: he stated.

column1: Analysts' reactions Reacting to THISDAY enquiries
column2: Head
column3: Intelligence and Research
column4: BGL Securities
column5: Femi Ademola
column6: explained tha
column7: t "If we use the performance of the Jaiz Bank over the years
column8: it shows that the specialised bank has grown quite impressively in the last three years
column9: increasing total assets from N14.11 billion in 2012 to N44.5 billion in 2014. Muharaba receivables which represents loans and advances in traditional banks also grew from N1.1 billion to N10.28 billion over the period; leading to increase in profitability from a loss of N728m in 2012 to a profit of N691m. This can be taken as a sign of good performance of non-interest banking over the period.

column1: With the increase in the amount of financing by the Jaiz Bank, it can be inferred that SMEs would benefit from funding from Islamic Banking. The fact that most of the financing granted by Jaiz Bank is to corporate customers also shows that the bank is ready to finance any organised SME, he stated.
However
column2: in a telephone interview with THISDAY
column3: an economist and Chief Executive of EZ Comms Resources
column4: Ezeh Wordu
column5: contended that before SMEs approach Islamic bank for funding it is important that the bank and the firm understand how the operations of the SMEs runs. He added that being an interest free banking makes it all the more suitable for SMEs to approach for funding compared to conventional banking considering the current exchange rate.

column1: Even though I am not a Muslim I wouldn't hesitate to approach Islamic Banking for funding to execute a project; the fact that it is interest free makes it more convenient for any SMEs; however, it is important that the bank understands the kind of business that the SME is into to forestall issues cropping up in future, Wordu stated.
Meanwhile
column2: an economist and banker with a third generation bank with head office in Victoria Island Lagos who spoke to THISDAY under the condition that he is not named stated that Islamic Banking or non-interest banking was a good source of funding for SMEs
column3: however noted that not all SMEs can access funding from the bank due to its strict compliance with Islamic law adding that the business line of the SMEs must however be Islamic compliant

column1: Islamic banking is restricted to islamically acceptable deals, which exclude those involving alcohol, pork, gambling. Unfortunately, this is a limitation on the kinds of SMEs that can approach the bank for funding. That said, it still remain a veritable source of funding for serious and well organized SMEs, he stated.
But speaking further
column2: Yusuf stressed that
column3: "Interestingly
column4: the most difficult funding challenge of small business is the problem of credit access rather than cost of credit. Many SMEs cannot meet the credit risk assessment criteria of the banks

column6: sometimes as high as 80 percent per annum. "The Islamic banking model has not gained much currency in the Nigerian economy because of its peculiar framework and possibly because of perception. column7: than say 50 percent of something. This is a major issue. The failure of the Small and Medium Enterprises Equity Investment Scheme [SMEIS] for SMEs was largely as result of this disposition of small business owners.

column1: The second key principle in Islamic finance is that there should be no reward without taking risk. Capital can only be rewarded if it is exposed to risk. This comes to the primacy of partnership. This again could be a limitation to the growth of Islamic finance. In partnership, trust is very critical; and in this environment, trust deficit is very high. Therefore, a financing concept that would be driven principally by character and integrity of players may be difficult to sustain. The risk management challenges in Islamic finance are enormous. This is why debt financing seems to be holding sway in the Nigerian economy.

Islamic banking industry came into existence in Pakistan when the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) issued the first full-fledged Islamic banking licence to Meezan Bank Limited under its 'Policy for promotion of Islamic banking-2003'. Subsequently
column2: the SBP issued full-fledged Islamic banking licences to other four commercial banks namely
column3: Dubai Islamic Bank
column4: Bank Islami Pakistan
column5: Burj Bank Limited and Al-Baraka (Pakistan Limited). Besides
column6: the other existing scheduled commercial banks were invited to apply for establishment as a full-fledged Islamic banks in the private sector or to set up subsidiaries and standalone branches. Under this policy
column7: it was explicitly stated that the banks
column8: which were permitted to do business as Islamic banking institution shall be subject to the prevalent banking and other laws
column9: rules and directives issued by the SBP from time to time. The dual banking model adopted by Pakistan is in line with the international practice as most of the Muslim countries have allowed the Islamic commercial banks to work parallel to the conventional banks.

column1: Since January 1
column2: 2003 till end June
column3: 2013 the branch net-work of the Islamic commercial banks has expanded more rapidly. The number of branches of the five full-fledged Islamic commercial banks were 661 compared with 369 established as subsidiaries and standalone branches by the existing conventional banks. Total number of Islamic bank branches
column4: therefore stood at 1030 as on end-June 2013.

column1: As per latest SBP's Annual Report
column2: total deposits mobilised by the Islamic banking industry stood at Rs 751 billion as on end June
column3: 2013 compared with Rs 581 billion registering a growth rate of 29 percent on year-to-year basis. Their share in total deposits of all the scheduled commercial banks increased from 9.3 percent to 10.5 percent during the same period.

column1: Total assets of the Islamic banking industry stood at Rs 903 billion with a market share of 9.0 per cent of Total Assets of all the scheduled commercial banks as on end June
column2: 2013. The latest available data (unaudited) for the quarter ended 31st December 2013 showed that total deposits and Assets of the Islamic Banking industry further increased to Rs 868 billion and Rs 1014 billion respectively fetching the respective market share of 10.4 percent and 9.6 percent as on the same date.

column1: The breakthrough achieved so far by the Islamic banking industry in Pakistan was not possible without the institutional infrastructure facilities provided by the State Bank of Pakistan and the Federal Government. The work on the subject was initiated in 1999 immediately following the announcement of the unanimous decision of the Appellant Bench of the Supreme Court
column2: which rejected the Federal Government's Appeal against the decision of the Federal Shariat Court
column3: which had declared the Profit & Loss sharing banking system introduced in July
column4: 1984 as interest-based banking system.

column1: In November
column2: 2002 the Banking Companies Ordinance
column3: 1962 was amended to pave the legal procedure for implementing the process of Islamization of the financial system in parallel with the existing commercial banking system. Before approaching the State Bank of Pakistan for obtaining the license for commencement of commercial banking it is mandatory for the sponsors to get their proposed bank registered as a public limited company under the Banking Companies Ordinance
column4: 1962 and also get their banking company listed on the country's Stock Exchange for mobilisation funds from the general public a minimum 50 percent of the authorised capital. Following these amendments the State Bank of Pakistan formulated a comprehensive criteria for the establishment of Islamic commercial banks and Islamic banking subsidiaries and/or standalone branches of Islamic banking by the existing conventional banks. The details of the Policy were issued to All Banks on January 1

column1: On the external front
column2: Pakistan joined as an active member of the leading International Islamic Financial Institutions like the Islamic Financial Services Board (IFSB)
column3: the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions (AAOIFIs) and the International Islamic Financial Market (IIFM). Pakistan's active association with these global Islamic links has been helpful in developing prudential and Shariah standards for the country's infant Islamic banking industry.

column1: A separate Islamic banking department has been created in the State Bank of Pakistan to oversee the functions of the Islamic banking institutions and to facilitate them to devise their legal and Shariah-compliance framework. In April 2014
column2: the Islamic banking department revisited the instructions and guidelines for Shariah-compliance which were issued to the Islamic commercial banks in 2008. The primary objective of the revised instructions on the subject is to strengthen the overall Shariah-compliance environment of the Islamic banking industry and explicitly define the roles and responsibilities of various organs of the Islamic banking industry including their Board of Directors (BOD)
column3: Executive Management (EM)
column4: Shariah Board (SB)
column5: Shariah's Compliance Department (SCD) and internal and external auditors of all Islamic banking institutions.

column1: The purpose of this paper is to make an independent assessment of the functioning of Islamic banking industry and to examine their capability to overcome the challenges and promises made by the country's political leadership right from Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah to the present government of Muslim League N) which has come into power as a result of the General Elections-2012. In his inaugural address at the time of opening of the State Bank of Pakistan the Founder of Pakistan and the first Head of State stated
column2: inter alia
column3: that the central bank authorities should endeavour to evolve banking practice compatible with Islamic ideas of social and economic life." the Quaid's vision about the Islamization process of the country's banking system must have remained alive on the minds of all the political leaders when they unanimously approved the 1973 Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan and promised
column4: inter alia
column5: to eliminate 'Riba' as soon as possible. No doubt
column6: all the succeeding governments in the country made their efforts to get rid of interest-based financial system

One cannot help note that the more lively debates in board rooms or evening majalis often relate to the merits and nuances of Islamic banking. The discussions have gained even more significance with the growing affluence in GCC
column2: and the keenness of a large segment of the population to align their economic affairs with their Islamic identity.

column1: In the process
column2: Islamic banking has gained broader acceptance in major international financial markets and there is ongoing research and studies on its merit as a viable alternative financial system.

column1: With the introduction of Islamic banking in Oman
column2: individual and corporate users have many queries on the Islamic finance system. In coming days
column3: the industry will need to address these through the conduct of their business as well as through structured awareness programmes.

column1: In this session
column2: Ernst and Young takes a look at some of the common questions being discussed by many Omani households and corporates.

column1: Start with an open mind
Islamic finance principles challenge the very fundamentals of the conventional economic theory. Money is seen as a medium of exchange and not as a commodity that generates incremental returns
column2: and this has major implications on the way banking transactions are done.

column1: Further
column2: Sharia only endorses three factors of production - land
column3: labour and entrepreneur
column4: and capital is considered a part of entrepreneurship and not the fourth factor.  Hence the concept of risk sharing.

column1: At the same time
column2: Sharia accepts the market forces of supply and demand
column3: allows governments to intervene in business affairs where necessary
column4: and recognises the right to private ownership and profit motives but all under the gambit of permissible means and activities. Sharia demands an equitable distribution of wealth
column5: achieved through the concept of primary and secondary ownership of wealth and the prohibition of interest.

column1: Perceptions and reality
Banking and insurance business is prohibited (haram)
Sharia has no objection on the banking and insurance activities. In fact individuals and societies are strongly encouraged to manage their wealth in an effective and productive manner.
Sharia does
column2: however
column3: object on the way conventional banking and insurance business is conducted today
column4: especially on the way the roles
column5: rights and rewards are determined for various parties in a transaction. Advocates of Islamic finance maintain that the relationships under Sharia contracts are more equitable in terms or risk and reward sharing.

column1: It is usury
column2: and not interest
column3: that is prohibited by Sharia

column1: There is no evidence that differentiates between usury and interest. Under Sharia laws
column2: money is strictly considered a medium of exchange
column3: and any incremental return on a loan is considered riba.

column1: Islamic banking is simply a change of terminologies
column2: calling interest as mark-up

column1: Islamic banking is fundamentally different from conventional system.
For example
column2: Islamic banks use permissible Sharia contracts to conduct transactions
column3: which define the risks and obligations of the bank and the customer differently from conventional banks.

column1: Also
column2: Islamic banks operate under a unique framework to ensure conformity to Sharia rulings. This framework is developed by global standard setting bodies on Sharia
column3: regulations
column4: governance
column5: accounting and business disciplines
column6: and are guided by eminent scholars
column7: academics
column8: bankers and regulators from across various jurisdictions.

column1: Most of these structural differences between conventional and Islamic banks may not be visible prima facie
column2: however they have significant implications on the risk profile and investment returns generated by Islamic banks.

column1: I pay interest on loans from conventional bank; Islamic banks are also asking me for an almost equal markup on all financing - where is the difference
There are two elements to this question. Firstly
column2: if Islamic banks are allowed to charge a markup on financing they provide
column3: and secondly
column4: why is it that this markup is so similar to prevailing interest rates.

column1: It is wrong to consider the funds with Islamic banks as free capital. Sharia does not prohibit Islamic banks from making profits. However
column2: these transactions have to be based on equitable contracts with implications on the rewards and obligations of each party.

column1: For example
column2: when a customer obtains car financing from a conventional bank and for some reason defaults on a payment
column3: he would typically be required to make a penalty payment to the bank under contractual terms. This penalty is booked as income for the conventional bank.

column1: When dealing with an Islamic bank
column2: the car financing may be based on Murabaha contract. If the customer defaults
column3: the Islamic bank would also ask for a penalty payment. However
column4: the rationale for this penalty is only to discourage defaults. Islamic bank may not book this penalty payment as income as Sharia prohibits re-pricing of Murabaha assets. The penalty is recorded in a charity account and subsequently donated. The transactions are monitored by Sharia compliance function and the Sharia supervisory board of the Islamic bank.

column1: The actual source of confusion is the conventional benchmark
column2: such as LIBOR
column3: that is used by Islamic banks when charging profit on financing or when paying returns on deposits. The industry is rather young
column4: and does not have its own pricing benchmark for reference.

column1: The use of conventional benchmarks has long been approved by Sharia scholars
column2: though it remains a source of continuing discussion and frustration in the industry.

column1: How can Islamic banks pay a fixed return on deposits
Returns on Islamic deposits are linked to the performance of the underlying pool of assets. As Islamic banks mature
column2: they are able to estimate the expected returns from the asset pool with more certainty. In addition
column3: the deposit contract typically allows the bank to allocate part of the profit to a reserve fund
column4: to be used in scenarios where investments returns are below expectations.

column1: This combination of financial expertise and safety net enables the Islamic bank to commit a certain return to Islamic depositors.
However
column2: there can be no guarantee on the investment returns
column3: and the same is reflected in the language of the deposit contracts.

column1: Can the same bank offer Islamic and conventional products
Yes
column2: a conventional bank may offer both Islamic and conventional products under certain circumstances. The pre requisite is to have a credible Sharia framework that clearly distinguishes between Islamic and conventional businesses. This is monitored by the regulator and the Sharia supervisory board of the bank.

column1: Is Islamic banking only about profit and loss sharing
No.  Islamic banks also offer Sharia compliant debt transactions
column2: leasing transaction
column3: Qard facility both on liability and asset side
column4: and other services.

column1: Is Islamic banking for Muslims only
Sharia compliant banking is relevant to the society at large
column2: regardless of their religious affiliation. Today
column3: many global institutions have added Islamic banking as part of their product offering to their customers in Muslim and conventional markets.  In fact
column4: many of the concepts of Islamic banking are similar to socially responsible or ethical banking practiced in Europe and North America.

column1: How Islamic is Islamic banking as it is practiced today
Contemporary Islamic banking is a small step in the right direction. In its current form
column2: it is certainly a bold attempt to avoid absolute haram
column3: by providing alternatives. Of course
column4: the industry still has a significant distance to cover to achieve its true goals.

column1: Sharia sensitive customers have an important role to play in this journey. You have a choice to start Islamic banking relationship with Islamic windows and banks. One also has the responsibility to challenge industry stakeholders to progress towards more authentic products and systems.
What to do with interest that one receives from conventional banks
Many scholars suggest that it is permissible to give this money away to help communities
column2: for example to orphanage
column3: schools or other provision of services in deprived societies. It is not permissible to accept this money for one's own benefit or for the benefit of one's dependents. Other options such as destroying this money or foregoing it in the bank's favour are also not encouraged.

column1: Final word
Over the coming days
column2: bank customers  in Oman will have a choice between Islamic and conventional products. Sharia compliance will be a necessary pre-requisite for some of these customers. For others
column3: the decision may also be influenced by the Islamic banks' offerings
column4: in terms of quality of service
column5: variety of products and customer care amongst others.

column1: While Islamic banking has tremendous potential for Oman
column2: the level of success will depend on the industry's investment in research and in developing the talent pool. At stake is the credibility of the system. Customers would want to see progress towards a holistic alternate financial system
column3: even if it has to be step by step process.

JEDDAH ? Turkey's Islamic banking assets are set to double within 10 years from a low level as government initiatives drive growth in the sector
column2: Moody's Investors Service said in a report published Monday.

column1: Turkey's Islamic finance sector currently is smaller than other large Muslim countries
column2: and its slow start means it has ample room to expand. The sector represented just over 5.8% of banking assets at the end of September 2019
column3: compared to Malaysia (33%) and Middle Eastern countries (15% - 77%).

column1: More than 95% of Turkey's roughly 83 million population is Muslim but Islamic finance penetration in the country is very low. The aggregate market share of Turkey's participation banks was 5.8% in September 2019
column2: compared with an average penetration rate of 43% in other Middle Eastern countries and Malaysia.

column1: The main reason is the relatively small number of Islamic banks and their limited distribution networks within Turkey. The sector market share has stagnated around 5.5% since 2014
column2: 1 lagging the 6 percentage points average increase in the penetration rate recorded in other Muslim countries.

column1: Islamic banks are called participation banks in Turkey and are regulated by the Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency (BRSA). They are required by law to become a member of the Participation Banks Association of Turkey (PBAT) - an umbrella organization defending the rights and interests of the country's Islamic banks. PBAT targets an Islamic banking penetration of 15% by 2025.

Islamic deposits (under Shariah law these are defined as investment accounts or funds collected) benefit from the same protection as conventional bank deposits under Turkey's deposit insurance and protection scheme. This enables them to attract funds from non- Muslim depositors.
There are six Islamic banks in Turkey. Three - Kuveyt Turk Katilim Bankasi A.S.
column2: Turkiye Finans Katilim Bankasi A.S. and Albaraka Turk Katilim Bankasi A.S. - have large shareholdings by Middle Eastern lenders. They dominate the sector with a combined market share of 76% of Turkey's Islamic banking assets at the end of June 2019.

column1: During the two years period between 2014 and 2015
column2: the Turkish government established two new state-owned participation banks and their market share is increasing. The new state-owned domestic lenders have intensified competition in the industry and are broadening the base of Islamic banking service provision. They are gradually building out extensive branch networks that will attract increasing numbers of Islamic banking customers in the coming years.

column1: The Kuwaiti-owned Kuveyt Turk issued the first sukuk in Turkey in 2010 with a face value of $100 million. Total sukuk issuance by Turkish Islamic banks amounted to TRY45 billion by the end of 2018. Annual sukuk issuance volume in 2018 was more than TRY16 billion ($2.7 billion)
column2: many multiples of the amount recorded at the start of the decade.

column1: The Turkish government made its debut sukuk issuance in 2012
column2: with two issues
column3: one domestic and one in foreign capital markets. Since then the Treasury has issued around TRY30 billion in the domestic market and $6 billion in international markets as a means to diversify its funding sources and attract capital from the Gulf Cooperation Council and other countries.

column1: The level of Islamic banking assets in Turkey remains low
column2: however
column3: there is ample room for the sector to grow. With the sector's strategic importance for the Turkish government
column4: dynamics of Islamic finance and banking are evolving and foundations for a period of significant Islamic finance growth are being laid. We expect Islamic banking to play a key role in Turkey's development of financial services over the next decade.

column1: Turkey's ambition is to establish Istanbul
column2: the country's largest city and its economic powerhouse
column3: as a global financial center. It aims to raise the share of financial services in Turkish GDP to 6% by 2023 from 3% at the end of 2018. Development of Islamic banking and finance is one of the key pillars set out in the seven-pillar framework called the Istanbul International Financial Centre Strategic Action Plan.

column1: Policies listed under the plan's Islamic finance pillar include raising public awareness of Islamic finance and banking
column2: establishing training to produce staff qualified in Islamic financial law and practices and broadening the range of Islamic financial products and services on offer to the Turkish population. The government has mandated Participation Banks Association of Turkey and the Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency (BRSA) to oversee or contribute to most of the Islamic finance policies listed in the IIFC strategic plan.

The country's largest Islamic bank witnessed an unusually good run in 2019
column2: according to its recently released financial statements. The sixth largest bank in Pakistan in terms of deposits
column3: Meezan Bank saw a 19% increase in its deposits in 2019. This is much higher than the industry growth of 10%.

column1: Its earnings per share hit Rs12.12
column2: or a 74% increase year-on-year
column3: while its return on equity touched 31% in 2019. Its profit after tax in the fourth quarter of 2019 also jumped 86% to Rs4.7 billion. Meanwhile
column4: net interest income - the difference between the amount of interest a bank can charge its clients on loans and the amount of interest it pays out its depositors - in the fourth quarter jumped 46%
column5: while other
column6: fee-based income jumped 95%.

column1: This unusually good run of earnings meant that even with a 30% increase in operating costs during that quarter
column2: the bank's efficiency ratio - the ratio between its operating costs and total revenue before adjusting for the costs of bad loans - actually managed to decline by 43%.

column1: Meezan Bank is part of the general wave of Pakistani banks that did well in 2019
column2: as higher interest rates
column3: particularly in the second half of the year
column4: lead to a recovery in the banking sectors' profitability on the whole.

column1: Yet even with interest rates set to decline in the second half of 2020
column2: the bank is optimistic that return on equity will remain within the 20-25% band. However
column3: the bank still has a somewhat prudent and cautionary approach
column4: moving forward.

column1: 'Advances reported a 4% year-on-year decline during calendar year 2019
column2: taking their advances to deposits ratio (ADR) down to 53%
column3: the lowest since calendar year 2015. The decline was a strategic decision as the bank desired to stay prudent in the ongoing economic slowdown and avoid any possible asset quality deterioration
column4: ' wrote Amreen Soorani
column5: research analyst at JS Global
column6: a securities brokerage firm
column7: in a note issued to clients on February 17.

column1: Continuing its 'prudent strategy'
column2: the bank booked general provisions worth Rs1.5 billion in 2019
column3: of which most was booked in the fourth quarter. The management is targeting a similar ADR in 2020 as in 2019. It also hopes to grow deposits in 2020
column4: aiming to cross the Rs1 trillion mark (or a growth of 13%).

column1: The bank already has 760 branches
column2: of which 100 were opened in 2019; it aims to open a further 150 in 2020. Meezan is the largest Islamic bank in the country
column3: an enviable position to be in considering the relative attractiveness of the Islamic banking market relative to the rest of the market.

column1: In the 15 years between 2003 and 2018
column2: deposits in the conventional Pakistani banking system have grown at average rate of 20.2% per year
column3: according to data from the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP)
column4: from Rs1.8 trillion to Rs13.4 trillion.

column1: That number is impressive
column2: until you take a look at the growth rate of the Islamic banking sector: during that same period
column3: deposits at Islamic banks and Islamic banking windows of conventional banks grew at an average of 65.1% per year
column4: from Rs14.4 billion to Rs2.2 trillion
column5: according to Profit's analysis of bank financial statements and State Bank data. Inflation during this period averaged 8.8% per year.

column1: To understand the magnitude of just how much of a difference that divergence in growth rates can make
column2: consider this fact: deposits in the conventional banking system are 6.3 times higher than they were 15 years ago. Islamic banking deposits in Pakistan are nearly 151 times higher over that same period.
Islamic banking constituted just 0.8% of all banking deposits. At the end of 2018
column3: that number stood at 16.2% of total deposits.

column1: What makes this rise particularly attractive for the banks
column2: however
column3: is that it does not come at the expense of their conventional businesses.

column1: 'A significant portion of Islamic banking customers come from populations that were previously unbanked
column2: thus creating a new revenue source for banks
column3: ' wrote Savina Joseph and Constantinos Kypreos
column4: two analysts at Moody's Investor Services
column5: the global ratings agency
column6: in a note issued to clients on Thursday
column7: September 19

column1: In short
column2: no bank can afford to not be in the Islamic finance business in Pakistan. The World Bank's Findex database estimates that
column3: as of 2017
column4: 79% of Pakistani adults did not have a bank account. And given the fact that Pakistan's population is 97% Muslim
column5: a substantial proportion of people prefer to use Islamic banking systems for their financial needs.

column1: While it is not possible to say with certainty what proportion of Pakistanis would prefer an Islamic bank over a conventional banking option
column2: there are some revealed preferences of consumers visible in the data: for every new rupee that came into the banking system in Pakistan in 2018
column3: about 30.3% went into the Islamic banking system and 69.7% went to the conventional system
column4: according to Profit's analysis of SBP and bank financial data.

column1: Over time
column2: Meezan has been able to dominate the Islamic banking market in Pakistan and has never really let go of its status as the country's leading Islamic bank
column3: with a market share of just over 36.2% in 2018
column4: a number that has remained largely steady over the past decade.

Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) governor
column2: Sanusi Lamido Sanusi
column3: may have succeeded in whipping up religious sentiments across the country with moves to institutionalise Islamic banking in the country. Finance Editor

column2: and Reporter
examine the rationale of Islamic banking against Nigeria's dwindling economy.

column1: Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) boss
column2: Sanusi
column3: is not new to criticism and controversies. But he may not have perceived the dimension his move to institutionalise Islamic banking in the country would amount. He drew the ire of some Nigerians when he told an Islamic forum in far away Senegal that Nigeria would soon embrace Islamic code of banking
column4: otherwise known as non-interest banking.

column1: We are working with the Debt Management Office (DMO). The Central Bank (of Nigeria) is collaborating with them on capacity building. We do have a target of issuing a first sovereign sukuk in Nigeria within 18 months, Sanusi had stated.
The process has just started; the decision (on amount issued) will be taken by the finance minister and the Debt Management Office.
Islamic banking is a form of banking where transactions are done within the tenets of Islam.
In the midst of raging controversy over Islamic banking
column2: Sanusi may have found support among analysts who argue that Islamic banking is good for the country.

column1: Chief executive officer
column2: Global Analysis Derivatives Ltd.
column3: Tope Fasua
column4: says that Islamic banking is good for the economy because
column5: according to him
column6: it would help mitigate risk.

column1: I think that Islamic banking is a risk-management tool at best. The precepts of Islamic banking helps mitigate against a few flaws of 'conventional' banking. On one hand, it seeks to avoid 'moral hazard', which is a scenario where bankers lend to their customers, simply for profit maximisation purposes (as represented by interest accruals), rather than because they are interested in the underlying project, or because they have a stake in the project. Islamic banking proposes that lenders may be part-owners of the project, and that means they must monitor the projects better and be concerned about the way the project is run, Fasua argues.

In this same vein, the concept of KYC (Know Your Customer) is taken care of. What we have under our type of conventional banking is a situation where marketers are put under immense pressure to bring in money from anywhere they can find it. Most of the marketers, if not all, are unaware of the loans to which the funds they bring in are applied. They are not encouraged to know. That is bad. Islamic banking does not operate that way.
Fasua argues further that Islamic banking is already a world-wide phenomenon.

Islamic banking is growing world-wide, but it is a present-day Nigerian sickness that we are religiously intolerant, or even bigoted on all fronts. Why must Nigeria become the last frontier of religious rivalry? I write from London, the land of our colonisers, and the Islamic Bank of Britain is all over the High Streets. Barclays and HSBC have Islamic products, some of the ethical products for people who do not want to invest in alcohol etc... Why can we not encourage that in our country? Fasua queries.
Corroborating Fasua
column2: industrialist and consistent critic of Nigeria's financial system
column3: Henry Boyo
column4: says Islamic banking is good if it is the same thing as non-interest banking (NIB).

column1: If Islamic banking has the same meaning as non-interest banking, then I believe it is a welcome development and should provide competition to the orthodox interest-based banks. As they say, competition is good for the consumer, Boyo says.
According to Boyo
column2: the former CBN governor
column3: Professor Charles Soludo's Small and Medium Enterprise Investment Scheme (SMEIS) is similar in many respects to the concept of non-interest banking.

column1: Unfortunately, Soludo chickened out under pressure from the banks and only a fraction of the funds collected to drive the scheme was utilised, Boyo emphasised.

Inexplicably, the fund was summarily terminated and the consolidated sum of about N40 billion was returned to the funding banks under the guise that beneficiaries of the scheme were concentrated in Lagos and preferred sectors of the South and the excuse that the banks did not have the capacity to superintend the multiple partnerships!
Toeing the same path
column2: principal consultant
column3: BIC Consulting
column4: Dr. Boniface Chizea
column5: says Islamic banking is nothing strange.

column1: The imperatives of Islamic banking forbid that interest is charged on loans. Instead, some form of profit-sharing arrangement is evolved, and there are other forms and schemes of financing that underpin Islamic banking. It is a form of banking mostly found in countries where Islam is the dominant religion and in most instances found in countries that have adopted Islamic jurisprudence unlike in Nigeria which is a declared secular state, says Chizea.

It is a fact that non-interest banking is found also in countries across the world that are secular such as Britain and the United States of America. Hitherto, in the country, Islamic banking services window were available in some conventional banks in the country notably Habib Bank before it was subsumed under the current Bank PHB following the consolidation programme of the banking industry. The first Islamic bank, Jaiz Bank, was licensed under the regime of the immediate past governor of the CBN, Soludo, but encountered some problems with mobilisation of the required minimum capitalisation of N25 billion.
According to Chizea
column2: with the recently heightened agitations and dangerous unrest underpinned by bombings
column3: there has been resentment regarding any programme
column4: scheme or service that would tend to undermine the secular status of the country and therefore little wonder that this mode of banking has encountered heightened opposition and resentment.

column1: However
column2: irrespective of the divide of opinions on Islamic banking
column3: one factor that many appear to have taken the backdrop is the economy.

column1: Analysts ponder the benefit Islamic banking holds for the Nigerian economy. According to them
column2: Islamic banking shouldn't be the pre-occupation of CBN when the economy is bleeding by the day.

column1: They easily point to the banking sector which they argue is still hanging in the balance.
If anything
column2: they argue
column3: the CBN should pre-occupy itself with how to revive and reposition the sector for the thriving of the economy.

column1: According to recent data from the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS)
column2: inflation rate has risen by 12.8 per cent.

column1: The Composite Price Index (CPI) rose by 12.8 per cent year-on-year (y-o-y) in March 2011. This is higher than the 11.1 per cent recorded in the previous month in the new CPI series. The monthly change of the CPI was 1.37 per cent increase when compared with the figure in February 2011, NBS reportedly disclosed.
The urban all items monthly index rose by 0.7 per cent, while the corresponding rural index declined by 1.9 per cent when compared with the preceding month.
Chizea says CBN should concentrate its energy on consolidating the banking sector rather than stoke controversy that would do the economy no good.
His words: "The Central Bank should be advised to concentrate
column2: for the time being
column3: on its prolonged battle to reform the banking sector by arriving at amicably acceptable modality for the recapitalisation of the 'rescued banks' in the country.

column1: The banking scene in the country is far from settled and this does not augur well for the ability of the banks in the country to perform their critical role of financial intermediation. It is only after that that the Central Bank would be seen to be justified to be embarking on this relatively novel banking scheme.
Corroborating Chizea
column2: Boyo says the potential of non-interest banking to support the real sector may not be realised.

column1: The potential of non-interest banking to support the real sector may not be realised because of the relatively attractive market for government borrowings. So, the cost of borrowing may not be radically affected by introduction of non-interest banking. Indeed, the expected returns from non-interest banking will inevitably gravitate to the level obtainable in the market; but this time, the spoils will be shared between the non-interest bank and their respective 'partners', Boyo argues.

The truth, of course, is that Islamic or non-interest banking would neither bring down interest rates nor reduce the rate of inflation. It will not strengthen the value of the naira or significantly impact on the level of employment positively.
But beyond economic benefits
column2: it seems that Banks and Other Financial Institutions Act (BOFIA) does not empower the CBN to license Islamic banks without recourse to the National Assembly.

column1: Associate professor of Law and Security Studies
column2: Babcock University
column3: Dr. Bankole Sodipo
column4: stated that the CBN Act and BOFIA do not support Islamic banking.

column1: The way forward is to look at the BOFIA and ensure that the move is in line with the Act. On the Advisory Council, there is no way they can delegate the decision-making of the body to another body because the National Assembly does not give them that power. The law does not regulate that form of banking because it shuts some people out. You don't give what you don't have and so you cannot give out what is not your own. What it means is that the CBN wants to introduce a form of banking through the backdoor, Sodipo argued.
Corroborating Sodipo
column2: chief executive officer
column3: Pharez Consulting
column4: Mr. Eghes Eyieyen
column5: argued that the introduction of Islamic banking is against the provisions in BOFIA.

column1: What is the inordinate drive and ambition behind the introduction of Islamic banking? To me, it seems as if the CBN is in a hurry to introduce it, and why does the CBN think it is going to be a major driver of financial institutions? It is not about religion; it is about the law and professionalism. Why has the CBN not given such passion and priority to the Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency of Nigeria (SMEDAN)? You cannot use a small provision in the BOFIA that gives you the power to regulate, to now begin to legislate, Eyieyen queried.
Buttressing Eyiyien
column2: a group known as Apostles in the Market Place (AiMP) in a document titled 'Re-purposing Capital: Non-Interest Banking in Nigeria' and signed by its executive director
column3: John Enelamah
column4: reportedly argued that Islamic banking would amount to introducing religion into banking.

column1: By insisting that non-interest banking products must be Sharia-compliant, the CBN has unjustly excluded non-Muslim Nigerians from engaging in non-interest banking business, AiMP network stated.
But there are others who argue that the CBN can license Islamic banking as far as it does not interfere with the secularity of the country.
Boyo agrees
column2: saying that CBN can license banks without recourse to the National Assembly but with a proviso that such a bank must not be based on religious or sectarian principles.

column1: The CBN has the powers to license banks, and BOFIA does not make it necessary for the CBN to seek the endorsement of the National Assembly to do so. However, in the event that the Constitution proclaims Nigeria to be a secular state, the CBN may be precluded from registering a bank based on religious or sectarian principles, in the same manner, for example, that the National Universities Commission (NUC) will not accredit a strictly faith-based university, Boyo said.
On his part
column2: Chizea says CBN can license banks without any religious nomenclature.

column1: From the perspective of the law, it allows the licensing of banks without any religious nomenclature. So if we settle for non-interest banking instead of Islamic banking, we would not be infringing upon the existing laws of the land. There, again, nothing is cast in stone, Chizea said.

If the Central Bank is intent on licensing purely Islamic banks, it could seek for the law in this regard to be changed through enlisting the cooperation of the members of the National Assembly. The same argument goes for the proposed establishment of Sharia Council at the Central Bank as it has been argued that given the mandate of such a body that it would realistically be composed with only the adherents of Islamic religion. And such a development might offend the secular status of the country.
Deputy governor of CBN
column2: Kingsley Moghalu
column3: argues that the CBN is pursuing banking and finance and not discrimination.

column1: From the view of the CBN, we are pursuing banking and finance and not discrimination. CBN is not making laws, but laws empower it to regulate the banks in the country, Moghalu stated.
In a related development
column2: terrorism has recently reared its ugly head in the country. Hence
column3: terrorism funding may have found its way into Nigeria's financial lexicon.

column1: There are apprehensions among Nigerians that Islamic banking may provide leeway for terrorism funding in the country. According to people on this divide
column2: the porosity of Nigeria's financial security system would make it viable for terrorism funding.

column1: Femi Awoyemi of Proshare Nigeria argues that terrorism funding does not need Islamic banking to thrive.
You do not need Islamic banking to exist before those seeking to fund terrorism thrive, Awoyemi says.

Proshare subscribes to the view that the not-for-profit financial institution as a banking model has its merits beyond religious demarcation. Whether the model will work well in our clime remains debatable in a secular society with strong commercial instincts and culture. The Islamic Bank of Britain (IBB) is a good case in point. There is, however, no known evidence linking Islamic banking and terrorism in any of the climes where it exists.
Corroborating Awoyemi
column2: Australian-based counter-terrorism financing expert
column3: Ganesh Sahathevan
column4: says it is even easier for terrorist groups to move money through conventional banks than Islamic banks.

column1: The easiest way in which a terrorist group can move funds around is through the conventional banking system, said Sahathevan.
But he cautions that Islamic banks have a greater propensity for facilitating the financing of terrorist groups at the level of ownership.

An Islamic bank is more often than not owned by Muslim shareholders who have a desire to promote Islamic banking as a form of Dawa (the prorogation and promotion of Islam). And among those who believe in the promotion of the Islamic way
column2: there are some for whom this may also include jihadist leanings
column3: Ganesh stated.

column1: So then, for a bank in the ownership of shareholders who already have that inclination, it becomes an obvious tool through which to move funds through the international banking system (for terrorism financing).
Stating further
column2: Sahathevan said terrosrist groups could exploit zakat (alms) to fund terrorism.

column1: Once you have a banking system feeding into zakat, then it becomes quite different, because there you're talking of very large sums of money... feeding into zakat, and then the zakat can be distributed by that very same banking network, he explained.
According to the expert
column2: once the money leaves the banking system through distribution to charity - which can then distribute it to other charities both locally and internationally - it becomes nearly impossible to trace.

column1: He argues that should money originally earmarked for buying Qu'rans or building religious schools in Pakistan be diverted once it arrives to an al-Qaeda training camp across the border in Afghanistan
column2: no one would be the wiser.

column1: On the way forward
column2: Chizea says there is no need for the controversies so generated by Islamic banking because Nigeria is a democracy.

column1: There is no need for all the controversies being currently experienced as the essential character of democracy is that all manner of interests as dictated by a major segment of the population must be allowed to thrive. And with appropriate guidelines and safeguards, there is no reason we should not accommodate this mode of banking in our land, Chizea advises.
On his part
column2: Boyo insists that until CBN's monopoly on Nigeria's dollar export is broken
column3: it would not achieve much economic development and growth even with Islamic banking.

column1: Enabling environment for economic growth and development will only evolve when CBN's monetary policy framework is overhauled and CBN's monopoly of our nation's export dollar holdings is broken, Boyo argues.

Double-digit interest rates, spiralling inflation, comatose industrial landscape, increasing debt burden, high fuel costs, increasing unemployment, etc are all the products of a payment system that ensures Nigerians become poorer when we earn more export dollars; a veritable contradiction brought about by CBN's substitution of naira for dollar component of monthly allocations to the three tiers of government.

This process instigates all the negative products of monopolies everywhere, and adversely affects resource allocations, efficiency, production costs and increasingly excessive money supply, which becomes the precursor of high lending rates and inflation.

column2: July 27 -- Many conventional banks in the country have shown interest to introduce Islamic banking. Some of them have already applied to the central bank for their conversion into Islamic banks. The Bangladesh Bank (BB)
column3: which is the main regulatory authority in the country
column4: has not yet given any permission to any of these banks. Newspaper sources confirm that the BB has decided not to allow any new Islamic bank or Islamic windows of conventional banks or such conversion permission until formation of a central Sharia Supervisory Council (SSC). Currently
column5: there is no central SSC to regulate or monitor Islamic banks in the country.

column1: Islamic banking is becoming more popular day by day in the country. According to the BB
column2: growth of deposits is more in Islamic banks than in conventional ones. In 2013
column3: deposit growth of Islamic banks was 25.83 per cent compared to 20.58 per cent in conventional banks.

column1: The reason for increasing trend of Islamic banking in Bangladesh or anywhere else in the world may well be attributed to its intrinsic value
column2: uniqueness of distinctive banking
column3: ethical and sustainability aspects. There is still a scope for further growth of Islamic banking in Bangladesh because the Muslims of this country are predominantly pious and prefer to satisfy their banking needs in a Shariah-complaint way. Therefore
column4: such conversion permission should be considered positively and the government should create supervisory and regulatory framework for facilitating such conversion.

column1: Although we have not seen any conversion in the country yet
column2: there are such examples existing in other countries in the world. The first conversion case took place when the National Bank of Sharjah became the Sharjah Islami Bank in 2002. So far
column3: the world has witnessed eight significant conversion cases: the Middle East Bank into the Emirates Islamic Bank (UAE)
column4: the Dubai Bank into the Dubai Islamic Bank (UAE)
column5: the NCB (Saudi Arabia)
column6: only retail banking
column7: the Khyber Bank (Pakistan)
column8: the Industrial Development Bank into the Jordan Dubai Islamic Bank (Jordan)
column9: the National Bank of Development into an Islamic bank by the ADIB (Egypt) and the Kuwait International Bank. Many banks are also in the process of being converted into Islamic.

column1: At present
column2: the BB controls
column3: guides and supervises this sector by incorporating some Islamic banking provisions in the amended Banking Companies Act
column4: 1991. Apart from this
column5: the BB issued guidelines for conducting Islamic banking in Bangladesh through a circular on November 09
column6: 2009. But the guidelines lack any guidance with regard to conversion to Islamic banking. The issue of developing a supervisory and regulatory framework for Islamic banks in the country is the pressing need now. The government should act on this issue while taking into consideration emerging issues like conversion from conventional banking to Islamic banks. A proper conversion guideline should be in place for facilitating such a transformation and of course in line with the practice of international standards.

column1: During their conversion into Islamic
column2: the banks face some challenges. These originate from the basic principles on which the Islamic banks run its operation
column3: that is
column4: providing banking services without taking resort to interest as it is prohibited in Islam. It may be felt from a layman's perspective that the services we get from Islamic banks are of those we also get from the conventional banks and the differences between the both are not distinguishable from each other. But a closer look at various issues will help clear the confusion. A look at the balance-sheet of both Islamic banks and conventional banks can clarify the matter.

column1: It is clearly evident from the tables that there is a difference between Islamic banks and conventional banks in terms of operational aspects. On the liability side of conventional banks
column2: it accepts demand and savings deposits
column3: issues term certificates such as certificate of deposits (CD)
column4: and has capital. On the asset side
column5: there is much more diversity and options in the form of marketable securities
column6: trading accounts
column7: lending to corporations and to consumers. On the liability of the Islamic banks
column8: it accepts demand deposits and various investment accounts while the asset side comprises financing assets where tangible goods and commodities are purchased and sold to customers
column9: investment assets

column1: The differences outlined above occur due to the fact that Islamic banks act as sorts of investment banks which collect deposits from depositors on Profit and Loss (PLS) basis and invest these deposits along with its own funds through various Shariah-complaint instruments.
Converting into Islamic bank: Issues and challenges
Converting into Islamic bank: Issues and challenges
If put simply
column2: depositors will deposit money in the banks for investment. Banks will invest this money and share the profit or loss within the guidelines of Shariah. Therefore
column3: the bank as a financial intermediary
column4: in modern setting
column5: will have PLS arrangements with both the depositors and with the users of the bank funds. This uniqueness of Islamic banking causes many challenges for any bank converting into an Islamic one among which the main three challenges are:

column1: Firstly
column2: dealing with interest income the banks have earned so far. Conventional banks normally receive interest from borrowers and pay interest to the depositors. The difference between these two is normally the main source of bank income. As Islamic banks do not accept interest
column3: the dealing with this income and the interest they have received and paid before the transformation is one of the challenges.

column1: The second challenge involves dealing with deposits received by the banks before transformation. Islamic banks receive deposits mainly on the basis of mudarabah and therefore
column2: banks will have to transform its deposits into mudarabah basis. It is to be mentioned here that all customers may not like the idea of mudarabah or Profit-or-Loss. Therefore
column3: banks will have to give depositors a choice for withdrawal. However
column4: giving choice for withdrawal is not easy as different deposits have different tenures before which withdrawal of such kind may incur loss to the depositors and banks also cannot force customers to withdraw deposits due to contractual obligation it made.

column1: The third challenge involves dealing with the loans given to customers on interest basis and arranging their transformation into equity-based investment. Like deposits

Islamic Banks have not yet been successful in creating an interest-free structure to place their funds on a short-term basis. They face the same problem in financing consumer loans and government deficits.

column2: initially of the Muslim population to conduct their business affairs according to syariah principles.

column3: issuing licences would not be feasible.

column1: So
column2: we considered another option. Why don't we allow all the banks which are interested in Islamic banking to offer it through windows as a product? So that overnight
column3: the whole country will have access. In order to compete

column5: our model has been reproduced worldwide as the most pragmatic model.

column5: which is big.

column6: although good

column4: own resources
column5: own capital.

column4: to enhance the linkages between Malaysia and the Middle East. So

column2: a different way of conducting the business. Instead of through a window

column4: I have no problem.

column1: This is probably one of the reasons why we are seeing more and more Malaysian banks spinning off their Islamic windows into standalone Islamic banks to enhance the attractiveness of the proposition to the Muslim community, Zhang said.

column2: which is banned in Islam. In the modern world
column3: that translates into an attitude toward money that is different  from that found in the West: Money cannot just sit and generate more money. To grow

column2: bankers designing investment instruments have to satisfy government regulators. In Islamic banking

column4: who study and review a product before issuing a fatwa
column5: or ruling
column6: on its compliance with sharia law.

column3: theoretically
