ISLAMIC banking is not just for Muslims. It caters to anyone who wants cost efficient funding
column2: and also wants the bank as a partner.

column1: That
column2: in a nutshell
column3: is how Abdulla Hasan Saif
column4: chairman of the newly established Islamic Bank of Asia (IBA)
column5: describes a banking system which
column6: despite having a client base of over half-a-billion people in over a dozen countries
column7: still remains largely an enigma.

column1: IBA
column2: Singapore's first stand-alone Islamic bank
column3: is a venture between DBS Bank and 22 other partners that are prominent families and companies in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries.

column1: 'Islamic banking distinguishes itself (from most traditional banking) by taking a long-term view
column2: and engaging in trade
column3: project financing
column4: and a whole host of other activities via partnerships with its clients
column5: ' says Dr Saif. 'It is not about short-term financing and deposit taking only.'

column1: And it would be a mistake to believe that IBA has been set up to cater exclusively to the Islamic population
column2: he adds. 'More and more
column3: people of different beliefs and cultural backgrounds are appreciating the role of an institution offering products in conformity with Syariah principles. Why? Because of the economics and cost effectiveness. Also
column4: there is more commitment from the bank.'

column1: Dr Saif was in town recently to officiate at the recent launch of IBA. The bank will focus initially on commercial banking
column2: corporate finance
column3: capital market and private banking services
column4: acting as a bridge for burgeoning capital flows between Asia and the Middle East. DBS currently holds a 60 per cent stake
column5: with its US$250 million investment
column6: but this will be diluted as more GCC funds flow in and IBA's capital eventually rises to US$500 million. However
column7: DBS will remain the majority shareholder with 50 per cent-plus-one share in the venture.

column1: Its Middle Eastern investors come from prominent families in the GCC countries
column2: including the owners of the Suhail Bahwan Group (Oman)
column3: Zamil Group (Saudi Arabia)
column4: Rana Investment Company (Saudi Arabia)
column5: The Kanoo Group (Bahrain)
column6: Dubai Investments (UAE) and Mohammed Abdulmobsin Al Kharafi & Sons Company (Kuwait).

column1: Besides chairman Dr Saif and vice-chairman and DBS boss Jackson Tai
column2: other members of the nine-member IBA board include Khalid Abdulla Al Bassam
column3: chairman of Bahrain Islamic Bank
column4: chairman of Al Bassam Investment Co and former deputy governor of Bahrain Monetary Fund; and Khalid Abdulla Al Zamil
column5: a partner in the Al Zamil Group of Companies. Singapore Telecoms' ex-chief Lee Hsien Yang sits on the board as well.

column1: Dr Saif himself brings with him an impressive resume which includes his current post as economic affairs adviser to the prime minister of Bahrain. A Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (UK) and holder of an honorary doctorate from the University of DePaul
column2: Chicago
column3: the 62-year-old also served as minister of finance and national economy of Bahrain
column4: and was a former governor of the Bahrain Monetary Agency
column5: the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank
column6: and the Islamic Development Bank.

column1: According to Dr Saif
column2: the idea of establishing an Islamic bank in Singapore was mooted during a series of high-level ministerial exchange visits between the leaders of Bahrain and Singapore almost two years ago.

column1: 'The suggestions by the two prime ministers sparked lots of interest and discussion within banking and business circles in the GCC states. And the idea gathered even more support in the GCC after two key promoters
column2: Khalid Abdulla Al Bassam and Khalid Abdulla Al Zamil
column3: came on board.'

column1: Dr Saif was then asked by the prime minister of Bahrain to present a proposal to Singapore
column2: where the government and financial regulators also saw potential for the venture. 'With the blessing of the authorities in Singapore
column3: including the prime minister
column4: senior minister and the officials of the Monetary Authority of Singapore
column5: we identified the partner
column6: which was DBS Bank. Our vision converged
column7: and so we devised a corporate plan. This entailed identifying the sectors we should focus on
column8: what would be the benefit of each sector
column9: how this would translate in terms of internal rate of return.'

column1: Modern Islamic banking started around the early 1960s largely catering to a small
column2: but fast-growing Muslim population in the Middle East who wanted financial services that conformed with Syariah laws. But over the past three decades
column3: the number of transactions and liquidity in the Islamic banking system worldwide have grown exponentially. Today
column4: the global Islamic banking system handles an estimated US$400 billion worth of assets every year. Analysts believe Islamic banking has also gained from the flight of capital eastwards following the 9/11 terrorist attacks in the US.

column1: Estimates suggest the assets and transactions handled by the Islamic banking system are growing at a rate of over 20 per cent per annum as the current network of some 200 Islamic banks in the Middle East and South-east Asia cater for a fast-growing global Muslim population.
In South-east Asia itself
column2: Malaysia is the undisputed leader in Islamic banking
column3: with both stand-alone banks and a network of thriving Islamic banking units within the conventional banking system.

column1: Hence
column2: the inevitable question which Dr Saif faces: Why base IBA in Singapore
column3: and why choose DBS Bank as the lead partner? 'DBS is the leading bank in South-east Asia. It is AAA-rated
column4: well run
column5: well managed. There is a lot of leverage that IBA can attain with DBS's backing and partnership. Our strategy was never to reinvent the wheel
column6: but to ride on the experience and knowhow that exist in DBS
column7: and even outsource some of the activities to DBS.'

column1: And Singapore? 'We had a list of centres where we could potentially set up the bank
column2: but we finally decided on Singapore. The financial market in Singapore is very well-developed and regulated. And given the critical mass of international financial institutions based here
column3: we will have no problem finding counter-parties. Also
column4: Singapore has a very transparent and forward-looking regulatory regime. This
column5: and its implications for governance
column6: is a huge factor for basing IBA in Singapore.'

column1: Dr Saif reckons the IBA is well-positioned to attract some of this Middle East capital further east to the Asia Pacific. 'This bank has the best on both sides of the balance sheet. The Far East is one of the fastest growing regions in the world
column2: with GDP growth at more than 9 per cent in some countries. So there is great potential for the bank
column3: given the assets that are available in the region.

column1: 'On the liabilities side
column2: all you need to look at is our shareholder profile. These are some of the most prominent families of the Middle East
column3: with their tradition and their wealth. It's a wonderful mix
column4: and the IBA will enjoy unique advantages
column5: headquartered in Singapore
column6: with access to Middle East capital and proximity to the fast-growing Asia Pacific.'

column1: No doubt
column2: the bank will have an eye on this region's 2.5 million high net worth individuals whose wealth is estimated at close to US$3 trillion (ex-Japan and ex-China). This wealth
column3: which has been growing at a rate of almost 7 per cent a year
column4: is expected to quadruple by the end of this decade.

column1: According to Merrill Lynch and CapGemini
column2: over a third of this wealth will find its way into alternative investments
column3: including Syariah-compliant funds and investments
column4: given the region's high concentration of Muslims (estimated to be over 500 million).

column1: But Dr Saif reckons the IBA will also attract strong interest from non-Muslims once they realise its potential and value proposition. 'Islamic banks operate on the basis that all transactions have to be halal. But halal does not refer to food only. Halal means Syariah compliant. So it has connotations to food products
column2: cosmetics products
column3: and distribution products. If you look at all these businesses that Islamic banking transacts
column4: the potential is over US$2 trillion. A quarter of it is in the food industry and the other quarter in the cosmetics industry. The remaining is in banking and distribution. So you can see the potential for such an institution.'

column1: But how does one educate the region's 300 million non-Muslims on the Islamic banking system's products and services? 'What we are doing is providing the client with a choice
column2: ' says Dr Saif. 'He now has to decide whether he prefers the product of the conventional banking system or the product of the Islamic Syariah banking system. He has to decide whether he will come to us to share the profit and accept the bank as a partner in Mudarabah
column3: or hedge against a commodity via Murabahah (or cost-plus financing).

column1: 'But I must emphasise there are many products engineered and offered by the Islamic banking system which believe in the principle of benefiting the client as well as giving the client cost effective financing. And these products have to be approved by the Syariah board
column2: who are scholars of the Islamic religion
column3: but who come from different countries and cultural backgrounds. That itself is an additional level of corporate governance we have.'

column1: But at the end of the day
column2: Dr Saif stresses
column3: IBA will have to prove its worth
column4: not just in the eyes of the Muslim population
column5: but within the wider financial world as well.

column1: 'The bottom line is
column2: the IBA is and will remain a commercial institution. It has to operate on economic principles and attain a reasonable return for its shareholders. In any case
column3: I am sure the regulator in the host country
column4: in this case the Monetary Authority of Singapore
column5: won't like to see an ailing institution struggling along here. IBA's role is to offer products which are acceptable and congenial to the requirement of its clients
column6: not just in the GCC
column7: but this region as well. It will hold its own against the other global banks here.'

HSBC Bank Malaysia Bhd has big plans formulated to enlarge its Islamic banking operations in Malaysia.
If it is awarded a licence to open a full-fledged Islamic banking subsidiary
column2: HSBC Malaysia's outgoing country chief Datuk Zarir J. Cama said the bank intends to hit the ground running
column3: rapidly opening between 20 and 30 Islamic bank branches within three years.

column1: But we are always preparing and are all ready. So, if the central bank is kind enough to give us the approval, we'll move very fast, he told Business Times in an interview in Kuala Lumpur. Cama is set to assume a new position at the group's headquarter in London next month after a four-and-a-half years service in Malaysia.
In Hong Kong last week
column2: HSBC's president and chief executive officer for Asia-Pacific said that its expansion into Islamic finance will not stop at just having branches.

column1: It it not ruling out the possibility of also applying for an international Islamic bank (IIB) licence.
While the plan remains remote for now
column2: Michael Smith told Malaysian and Indonesian journalists that the bank would keep it under consideration.

column1: He said HSBC's international Islamic financing deals are now conducted through its office in Dubai and some out of its headquarters in London and the Hong Kong office.
Under the Malaysia International Islamic Financial Centre (MIFC) initiative
column2: an IIB is allowed to conduct a wide range of Islamic banking business in Malaysia under the Islamic Banking Act 1983 with non-residents in international currencies other than the ringgit.

column1: The IIB is eligible for full tax exemption for 10 years and the eligibility criteria include a well-capitalised and reputable licensed financial institution with a sound track record and adopting international banking practices.
Smith said for now
column2: HSBC's Islamic unit in Saudi Arabia is the biggest but with Malaysia's commitment to become the regional hub for Islamic banking
column3: HSBC will naturally use Malaysia as a platform to spread its Islamic banking expertise in the region.

column1: HSBC Malaysia has been operating Islamic banking activities through a window
column2: or as part of the conventional bank. Having a full-fledged subsidiary licence would mean that it can open separate branches just for Islamic banking activities
column3: competing with other Middle Eastern banks such as Kuwait Finance House (KFH) and Al-Rajhi Bank. KFH recently announced plans to open 10 branches a year in the next few years
column4: while Al-Rajhi is planning to boost its branches to 50 by 2010
column5: from 12 currently.

column1: Cama said HSBC Malaysia?s Islamic banking operation is now the largest among the
locally-incorporated foreign banks.
As a key player in global Islamic finance
column2: he said HSBC can contribute significantly to Malaysia?s effort in developing this sector.

column1: In the global level
column2: HSBC is no stranger to Islamic financial products. It is the world?s largest player in the Islamic bond
column3: or sukuk
column4: market.

column1: With the reach of more branches
column2: the bank would be able to bring its expertise in Islamic capital market and strong investors network to benefit smaller Malaysian companies
column3: Cama said.

column1: A good example was Khazanah Nasional when we did their exchangeble bond. They were looking for Islamic investors out of Middle East and we are the bank that could bring the largest amount of Islamic investors because we have a very strong customer base in Middle East, Cama said.
Other banks have less capabilities in this area, he remarked.
He said the planned Islamic bank branches would give HSBC greater scope to reach a different class of customers and allow it to structure similarly sophisticated deals for smaller firms.
Through the subsidiary
column2: it is also hoping to establish a stronger branding in syariah-compliant sector and attracting those who did not bank with HSBC in the past simply because it was not seen as an "Islamic bank".

column1: A full-fledged Islamic banking subsidiary also fits in well with the group's plan to use Malaysia as a regional hub for Islamic finance
column2: assisting its growth in Indonesia
column3: Brunei and Bangladesh.

column1: In Malaysia
column2: Islamic banking has helped the bank rake in record profit last year.

column1: The bank's profit before tax and zakat of RM949 million was 28.8 per cent higher than the previous year.
Income from Islamic banking operations jumped 65.7 per cent to RM179 million
column2: as loans expanded
column3: especially personal instalment loans.

column1: Islamic banking assets now account for about 12 per cent to 13 per cent of HSBC Malaysia's total assets
column2: and Cama is confident that it will reach the 20 per cent target set by Bank Negara Malaysia by 2010.

column2: there are bright spots for Islamic banking in the Philippines as it will open investment opportunities and will give a boost to the Bangsamoro region and the local halal industry
column3: according to analysts.

column1: They noted
column2: however
column3: that the expansion of the sector may be gradual over the medium-term given the lack of a developed Islamic finance infrastructure.

column1: ?The BSP?s (Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas) approval of a law on Islamic banks and Islamic banking units
column2: as well as building up an enabling environment for Islamic banks and Islamic finance
column3: may help to support the Philippines? efforts to form a cohesive Islamic finance regulatory framework
column4: ? Bashar Al Natoor

column1: Given that Islamic financing is still a new concept in the Philippines
column2: Mr. Al Natoor said it will be important to monitor whether this framework could bring in more foreign direct investments (FDI) ??in particular from the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)
column3: and whether we will start to see a series of potential mergers and tie-ups in the Philippines.?

column1: Mohamed Damak
column2: Senior Director and Global Head of Islamic Finance at S&P Global Ratings
column3: also pointed out Islamic banking?s potential to help attract investment flows.

column1: ?It can also help the country attract investors from Muslim countries that are attached to Sharia compliance
column2: ? Mr. Damak said in an e-mail.

column1: FDI in the 10 months to October stood at $5.79 billion
column2: falling 32.8% from the $8.61 billion in the same comparable 2018 period. The BSP?s downgraded FDI target for 2019 is $6.8 billion.

column1: According to Mr. Al Natoor
column2: Islamic financial institutions from the GCC are keen not only for mergers and acquisitions with domestic lenders but are also eyeing cross-border deals.

column1: ?This has been an instrumental tool in developing Islamic finance outside the Gulf
column2: similar to what we saw in Morocco
column3: Turkey and other emerging Islamic finance markets
column4: ? he said.

column1: Only the Al Amanah Islamic Investment Bank of the Philippines operates under Shariah principles among the lenders in the country. The Zamboanga- headquartered lender was absorbed by the Development Bank of the Philippines in 2008.
BSP Deputy Governor Chuchi G. Fonacier earlier said one foreign Islamic bank has expressed interest in setting up branch in the country
column2: adding that several local players are also considering to go into offering Islamic banking for their clients.

column1: In August
column2: Republic Act No. 11439 or the act providing for the regulation and organization of Islamic banks was signed into law.

column1: Among its provisions is to allow traditional banks to secure Islamic banking operations subject to approval from the Monetary Board (MB).
Islamic banks are allowed to issue Shariah-compliant funding instruments
column2: including ?sukuk? upon the MB?s approval
column3: in order to utilize it for lenders? operations and other capital needs.

column1: Such banks are asset-backed with operations that do not involve ?riba? or interest in accordance to Islamic principles.
BARMM
Tengfu Li
column2: Financial Institutions Group Analyst at Moody?s Investors Service
column3: said the establishment of an Islamic banking framework will help boost growth in the newly established Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM).

column1: Mr. Li said in an e-mail that Islamic banking will be able to ?complement the local halal industry
column2: and help open up trade and investment opportunities with GCC and neighboring Muslim-majority countries.

column1: Provinces making up the BARMM include Lanao del Sur
column2: Sulu
column3: Maguindanao
column4: Basilan
column5: Tawi-Tawi
column6: as well as Cotabato City.

column1: The Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
column2: which is the precursor of the BARMM is currently one of the least banked regions in the country
column3: Fitch?s Mr. Al Natoor noted.

column1: ?[T]hough its economy has grown by an average of 7.2% to 7.5% over 2017- 2018
column2: faster than the national average (6.2% to 6.7%). This further highlights the potential for Islamic banks to grow in the region
column3: ? he added.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: S&P?s Mr. Damak said the country could tap into the sukuk market to boost investments and to diversify funding sources.

column1: ?Several non-core Islamic finance countries tapped the sukuk market including for example South Africa
column2: the UK
column3: and Hong Kong. While the pricing might be similar to conventional bonds
column4: and the process might be more complex
column5: such sukuk issuance can help investors base diversification
column6: ? Mr. Damak said.

column1: The analysts said initial pain points for would-be Islamic bank players in the country would be in trying to put a competitive edge against traditional products as well as structures relating to Shariah compliance.
Moreover
column2: they acknowledge that there will be need to establish awareness of new product offerings.

column1: ?The hurdles would be mainly related to the complexity of putting together Islamic finance transactions in a competitive way compared with conventional
column2: ? Mr. Damak said.

column1: ?Complexity relates to the Islamic structures themselves
column2: Shariah interpretation
column3: and the regulatory environment
column4: ? he added.

column1: ?A shortage of competent Islamic banking professionals will also constrain their ability to expand
column2: ? Moody?s Mr. Li said.

column1: For his part
column2: Fitch?s Mr. Al Natoor said establishing ?greater consumer awareness and trust? will take time given the constraints coming from limited funding sources and the lack of public knowledge in the country with regard to Islamic financial services. He said this is also the case even for countries with a Muslim majority such as Morocco.

column1: ?While its [Morocco?s] first Islamic banking licenses were issued in 2017 and despite rapid growth (110% between June 2018 and April 2019)
column2: Islamic banking still accounted for less than 1% of the banking sector?s total loans at end-2018
column3: ? he said

column1: He also cited other countries with a majority population of Muslims such as Turkey and Indonesia saw ?strong growth? of Islamic banking at the onset but steadied to secure only around 5% to 6% of the total lending in the banking system.
For S&P?s Mr. Damak
column2: support from regulators would help an industry still in its early stages.

column1: ?One specific example is having a central Shariah board at the level of the central bank for example and which would have the ultimate authority for matters related to Shariah compliance
column2: ? he explained.

column1: Aside from this
column2: Mr. Damak said leveling ?the playing field in terms of tax and prudential regulation treatment to avoid putting Islamic finance at disadvantage compared with conventional finance? will help Islamic banking take off in the country.

column3: Saeed Ahmed in his presentation said that since the re-launch of Islamic banking in the country
column4: the SBP has accepted the dual responsibility as regulator and facilitator.

column1: Endorsing the importance of the first RTC on Islamic Banking by media in 2014Mr. Saeed Ahmad recalled that in the first round table conference the federal finance minister Ishaq Dar has acknowledged the demand of the conference for appoint of a deputy governor exclusively for promotion of Islamic banking in Pakistan. column2: he said
column3: from April 01
column4: all concerned banks would be required to ensure Shariah governance with members conversant in Shariah to keep vigil on banking. ?Training of management as well as of board members in Islamic banking would be ensured
column5: ? he said. Saeed Ahmed
column6: who is also the Deputy Governor of the SBP
column7: responding to comments made by President Mamnoon Hussain
column8: said a Centre of Excellence in Islamic banking is also on card with major focus on research. ?For the purpose experts from finance
column9: economic and Shariah are being involved to streamline and strengthen Islamic banking

column1: Speaking on the occasion Meezan Bank President and CEO Irfan Siddiqui said that he had taken start of Islamic banking in 1997 and started formally with first six branches in 2002. ?Today Meezan Bank has 450 branches all over the country due to not only struggle
column2: hard work
column3: but a hope and public demand
column4: ? Siddiqui added.

column1: ?Today
column2: there are five Islamic banks with 1600 branches in the country and 17 conventional banks have opened Islamic banking windows keeping the growth of faith-based banking system in view
column3: ? Siddiqui highlighted.

column1: Pakistan
column2: which was established on principles of Islam
column3: has 200 million population and

column1: the country has huge market as far as Islamic banking is concerned. ?I have started Islamic banking with a vision
column2: which I see is going to be materialized
column3: and I would request to the banks to take Islamic banking as a passion instead of a need of hour
column4: ? Siddiqui said
column5: adding that ?If you take Islamic banking as a need then you will get results
column6: but if you take it as a passion
column7: then you will get outstanding results said Irfan Siddiqi

column1: Siddiqui said: ? When I had started Islamic banking then I came to know that we would capture 10 percent of the population only and it was evident from the survey at that time.?

column5: ? Dar vowed. National Bank of Pakistan (NBP) President Iqbal Ashraf has said that keeping the popularity of Islamic banking in view
column6: NBP has transformed 150 conventional bank branches into Islamic bank branches. ?We have requested the SBP for opening 55 more new Islamic bank branches and waiting for permission of the central bank
column7: ? Ashraf added.

column1: ?Last year
column2: we reviewed that the Islamic banking is growing much faster as compare to the conventional banking and the government is playing its role in flourishing faith-based banking industry
column3: then we have decided to transform some conventional bank branches into Islamic bank branches
column4: ? Ashraf recalled.

column1: ?As we have started Islamic banking
column2: we got positive results
column3: ? Ashraf said
column4: adding that ?We have decided to open more Islamic bank branches as NBP will not lag behind in the race of Islamic banking industry.?

column1: Hasan Bilgrami:
BankIslami Pakistan Limited President and CEO Hasan A Bilgrami said that BankIslami is serving to the Islamic banking industry in the country since last eight years. ?Before launch of the bank
column2: we have conducted a survey and it has come to know that Islamic banking would get popularity in urban parts of the country as compare to rural area
column3: ? Bilgrami said
column4: adding that ?The only reason behind this finding was that the people living in urban parts of the country are educated as compare to rural areas.?

column1: ?Later
column2: we conducted another survey to know the strength of Islamic banking industry
column3: ? Bilgrami said
column4: adding that ?The findings of the survey has revealed that a bank branch of Islamic bank has achieved a target in just four years as compare to the commercial bank branch which achieved the same targets in 40 years.?

column1: Mufti Muhammad Najeeb Khan:

column2: Habib Metropolitan Bank Limited Shariah Advisor Mufti Muhammad Najeeb Khan urged to make legal framework for Islamic banking industry. Showing his apprehensions
column3: he said that the Islamic bank will face problems in facing default cases in the court as Islamic banking industry has no legal framework.

column2: we have introduced Islamic banking
column3: but could not bring the growing industry in the legal framework as yet
column4: ? he observed. We should gather all stakeholders under one umbrella and if we ignore any stakeholder then we will have to face problems from the ignored stakeholder

Almost three-fourth of Pakistanis using bank accounts prefer switching to Islamic banking and are even willing to share the losses if any incurred upon thereof
column2: State Bank of Pakistan (SBP)'s report on Islamic banking reveal.

column1: The banking regulator has predicted that there is overwhelming potential demand for Islamic banking in the country and if proper awareness is created significant number of new entrants can be attracted to the industry.
The report has highlighted the growth of Islamic banks from 2003 to 2013 according to which during the period 2003-2013
column2: net financing and investments have seen impressive growth from Rs10 billion to Rs709 billion. By end of December 2013
column3: total size of net financing and investment reached by 8.5 percent. Since 2008 the growth of investments in federal government securities has increased from Rs 9.62 billion to Rs 267 billion by the end of December 2013. Out of the total Islamic banks investments
column4: government securities approximately account for 70 percent.

column1: The report regarding knowledge
column2: attitude and practices of Islamic banks in Pakistan predicts bright future of the Islamic banking in Pakistan and suggested few recommendation for the Islamic banking system to leave the conventional banking system behind.

column1: The special report which has been prepared with the support of Department for International Development (DFID) also included survey questions about the Islamic banking system.

The report reveals that overall 74 percent respondents who have bank accounts either in conventional banks or Islamic banks are willing to switch to Islamic banking system thus showing there is a strong willingness to switch whereas 26 percent stated that they would not switch or unsure of switching to Islamic banking.

Another interesting aspect which this report reveals is that irrespective of whether conventional products are cheaper than the Islamic products 62 percent of banked respondents were willing to pay more for Islamic banking products because these are Sharia compliant. A significant number of respondents are willing to use purely profit loss sharing accounts as compared to those that provide capital guarantee and certainty of returns. More than 6 in 10 respondents using both Islamic or conventional banking were willing to accept the risk of loss. 36 percent have even stated that they would not remove their money if the bank announces loss.

As much as 51 percent of banked respondents prefer to be customers of only full fledged Islamic bank while remaining 49 percent expressed that they would accept the option to bank with Islamic branch/window model. However among the later mentioned group
column2: 14 percent stated that they were comfortable in dealing with the conventional bank offering Islamic services whereas 22 percent expressed better customer services to be necessary condition for choosing an Islamic bank while remaining 14 percent said that they would use an Islamic window only if it was guided by Sharia scholars that they trust.

column1: For those that are interested in Islamic banking , religious satisfaction derived from Islamic banking products and the absence of interest were the most important reason for switching to Islamic banking. Interestingly profit and loss sharing was the third most important reason for both banked and non banked. While the reputation of the bank and the availability of a range of Sharia compliant product were relatively less important, the report says.

The report has pointed out a major reason of slow pace of Islamic banking penetration in the country and predicted that the presence of Islamic banking branch would bring a significant increase in switching from conventional banking to Islamic banking as 69 percent of those who are willing to switch reported there is no Islamic bank branch in their locality. 65 percent of non banked explained that there is no Islamic bank in their locality but 79 per cent felt that they are not banking Islamically because Islamic bank have not approached them.

Another important result coming from the survey is the willingness of majority of the corporate (more than 50 percent) to access PLS based financing. This is contrary to the perception that there is no demand for such financing among corporate
column2: the report points out.

column1: There is significant demand for Islamic banking amongst retail and business in Pakistan. It follows from the analysis that while overall demand for Islamic banking amongst the retail is higher than the businesses (nearly 95 percent for household and about 73 percent for businesses). The effective demand for Islamic banking amongst business and individuals also remain consistant (26 for business as opposed to 65 percent individuals).
While highlighting the Islamic financing portfolio
column2: the report says
column3: more than 70 percent of total Islamic financing portfolio is represented by the corporate sector
column4: followed by consumer finance(11.6 percent). Most of the corporate financing is extended textile 19.1 percent
column5: energy 8.9 percent and chemicals and pharmaceuticle 6.3 percent. The SME sector represents only 5 percent of the total financing along with the agriculture and these two sectors are the most neglected sectors.

column1: Interestingly the ratio of Non Performing Financing which has increased significantly from 2008 to 2013 but in the Islamic banking it is much low than the conventional banking which is 5.7 percent in December 2013 but encouragingly it is still below the overall banking industry average of 12.7 percent.
According to this report
column2: the complete switch from the conventional to Islamic banking will take some time as banking relationship tends to be sticky. 68 percent of the users of Islamic banking have been with the present system for less than three years indicating that there has been a significant rise in the numbers of customers over the last few years. 44 percent have been using the Islamic banking services for 1-3 years slightly under 24 percent of the respondent have been using services for less than a year.

column1: The study shows that there is not much difference between the users of conventional and Islamic banking in terms of educational background
column2: although Islamic banking users tend to be more educated that the conventional banking users. Majority of Islamic banking users are from urban areas.

column1: There are proportionally less government employees who deal with Islamic banking institutions with a relatively small number of respondents using Islamic banking services associated with this profession.

It is recommended in the report that a favourable decision of government to use Islamic bank for disbursement of salaries would not only provide a stimulus to growth of the industry but also create awareness among this segment of the society. The remaining other sectors have less representation.

The report has also highlighted the fact that majority of the Islamic banking users are satisfied with the services of the banks. 89 percent of the Islamic banked were satisfied with their banking services. Three most important factors contributing to satisfaction were i) Islamic products are not based on interest
column2: ii) they provide religious satisfaction and comfort
column3: iii) Islamic bank employees are helpful.

column1: Overall 84 percent of Islamic banked respondents stated that they would recommend others to utilise Islamic banking services. This is five percent less than the number of respondents who were satisfied with the Islamic banking services
column2: but the high percentage of those who would recommend nevertheless bodes well in terms of spreading knowledge and information about Islamic banking.

column1: From among the businesses surveyed 86 percent chose Islamic banking because the owners were religiously motivated. Similarly the report suggests that services quality of Islamic banking is better than the conventional banking which suggests that the Islamic banks are going beyond their religious proposition and attempting to compete with the conventional banks, the report says.
The report has suggested some recommendation for the growth of Islamic banking net. As per report these three areas are
column2: rural areas
column3: SME and agricultural financing and micro-finance services and they must develop some innovative products. For this purpose they need to invest more into research and development by themselves of seeking external support.

column2: March 31 -- From a humble beginning in the 1960's in Egypt
column3: Islamic banking has witnessed a significant development in terms of growth and size. With 15 per cent -20 per cent growth annually
column4: Islamic banking has widened its horizons to all major parts of the world. Islamic banking is now operating in more than 75 countries of the world.

column1: THE THEORETICAL WORK: With Islamic resurgence throughout the Muslim world in the 1940s and 1950s
column2: a serious attention was given to the social
column3: political and economic dimension of Islamic system and the idea of Islamic banking or interest-free banking arose.

column1: In the pre-Islamic era financing principles were either riba-based or mudarabh and musharakah-based. Since Interest (riba) is prohibited in Islam
column2: the jurists of the early-Islamic period closely examined the feature of mudarba and mushraka and developed a detailed framework of juridical opinion in regard to these two types of arrangement to make them fully compatible with shariah. The abundance of juridical opinions of these two types of arrangement actually laid the foundation of the modern Islamic banking theory.

column1: Among the earliest proposal for Islamic banking
column2: one was made by Qureshi (1946) in his book Islam and Theory of Interest. He suggested that both Islamic bank and entrepreneur can create partnership. However
column3: his notion of partnership was unclear as he suggested that capital will be provided by one party and work will be done by the other while profit and loss will be borne by two parties. Ahmed (1952) in his book Economics of Islam
column4: reiterated the same view with a proposal for establishing Islamic banks on the basis of joint stock company with limited liabilities. He held the view that customer could deposit their capital on the basis of partnership. Later contributions such as Uzair's (1955)
column5: Irshad (1964) Al- Arabi (1966) also suggested that mudrabah should be the main principle for Islamic banking.

column1: Siddki (1985 - in Urdu language published in 1968) provided elaborate theoretical foundation of Islamic banking and detailed framework of financial intermediation. His proposed Islamic banking mode on the basis mudaraba and musharakha classified the operations of Islamic bank into three categories: Service-based on fees
column2: commission and other fixed charges
column3: financing on the basis of mudarbah and partnership and service provided free of charge

column1: Chapra (1985) proposed the concept of Islamic banking on the same PLS (profit and loss sharing) basis and for the first time he promoted the idea that Islamic financial institutions are investment institutions rather than typical financial institutions. His idea of banking was in line with the proposal of earlier scholars and provided a much more fertile ground for profit and loss sharing arrangements in the banking models. He further developed the idea that Islamic banks should serve the public interest rather than individual or group interest.
Hence
column2: they should play a social-welfare-oriented role rather than a profit maximising role. Contemporary writings also emphasised that Islamic banking should participate activities towards achieving the socio-economic objectives of poverty eradication
column3: equal distribution of wealth and income and crediting ample employment opportunities which can best be achieved thorough PLS techniques

column1: PLS-based models
column2: such as two-tier mudaraba
column3: were the fundamental principle for banking in the earliest theory. Under this theory
column4: Islamic banks as intermediaries would avoid interest from all their operations and rely on partnership and profit-sharing instead. They can operate demand deposits like their conventional counterparts and like banks
column5: offer other services against fees.

column1: However
column2: practitioners of Islamic banks
column3: especially
column4: in the Arab world did not see much scope in this model. It was also challenged by scholars as regards its application in modern banking system as it lacked ability to provide financing for consumer goods and goods supplied to government and industry etc. Therefore
column5: during the 1970's and 80's
column6: a significant development occurred in terms of proposing other principles that are shariah-complaint in one hand and are capable of meeting the demands of growing customers who wanted the same sort of products they used to get from conventional banks
column7: on the other. The most significant development during that period was the introduction of sale-based principals. Based on the Quranic verses (2:275) which clearly distinguished bai (trade) and riba (interest)
column8: the Fiqh scholars mentioned following five forms of deferred sales which became the cornerstone of non-PLS-based principles in Islamic banking and granted added capacity to Islamic finance to offer liability creating financing or debt-based financing :

column1: 1. Salam Sale - In this type of sale
column2: the price is paid at the time of contract and the object of sale becomes due as debt in kind.

column1: 2. Muajjal Sale - The object of sale is delivered at the time of contract but the price becomes due as debt.
3. Istisna Sale - The price is paid at the time of contract and the object of sale is manufactured and delivered later.
4. Ijarah Sale - Sale of the usufruct of the assets in exchange of periodic rentals.
5. Murabaha - Sale with known profit which may or may not create debt.
FROM THEORY TO REALITY: While the first theoretical work began in the 1940s
column2: the experimental work in this regard did not start until 1960. In 1963
column3: the Mit-Ghamr Islamic Savings Bank (MGISB) started in Egypt which is regarded as the first Islamic bank in the world.

column1: However
column2: a number of scholars
column3: such as Wilson
column4: Traute and Siddiki
column5: pointed out that a number of interest-free saving and loan societies are reported to have been established in the Indian subcontinent during 1940s. According to Traute (1983) and Wilson (1983)
column6: an attempt was made to establish an Islamic bank in the late 1950s in a rural area in Pakistan
column7: though this had no lasting impact.

column1: On July 25
column3: a pioneering experiment
column4: the Mit-Ghamr Islamic Savings Bank (MGISB)
column5: started in the county of Mit-Ghamr in Egypt. The purpose was to mobilise the idle savings of the majority of the Muslim Egyptian population without violating the laws of the Shari'ah and to provide them with halal returns on their savings as well. The experiment proved quite successful and the savings mobilisation was impressive. It came to an end in February 1967 after only three and a half years due to political reasons beyond its control.

column2: Malaysia established Pilgrims Fund Corporation or Tabung Haji
column3: which started operation with the objective of enabling Malay Muslims to save gradually for expenditure during Hajj (pilgrimage)
column4: facilitating active and effective participations in investment activities that are permissible in Islam through their savings. In 1973
column5: The Phillipine Amanah Bank was also established to enable Muslims to meet some of their financial needs without involving interest.

column1: Institutional involvement began in 1970s and the Islamic Development Bank (IDB) was established. It was founded in 1973 by the Finance Ministers at the first summit of the Organisation of the Islamic Conference with the support of the king of Saudi Arabia at the time and began its activities on October 20
column2: 1975 at Jeddah
column3: Saudi Arabia. It's initial share capital was supplied by its member countries. The main objective of IDB is to foster economic development and social progress of the member countries and Muslim communities individually as well as jointly in accordance with the principles of shariah.

column2: Faisal Islamic Bank was established in Egypt and Sudan. During the same year Kuwait Finance House was set up by the Kuwaiti Government.

column1: Within ten years since the establishment of Dubai Islamic Bank
column2: more than 50 Islamic banks came into being not only in Muslim countries but also in some of the Europe countries. Islamic banking has spread its horizon to all major parts of the world. column16: large conventional banks that have opened Islamic windows include HSBC
column22: and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

column1: Efforts have also been made to introduce Islamic bank at state level as well. Islamisation of banking system in Pakistan started in 1979 and continued until 1985 through a series of ordinances issued by the central government and a number of circulars issued by the State Bank of Pakistan. Iran introduced usury-free banking laws in 1983 and nationalised all banks in the country.

Sudan launched Islamic banking in 1984 and made entire financial sector Islamic in 1989. Malaysia introduced Islamic banking in 1983 by introducing Islamic Banking Act. Malaysia's effort in this regard is unique as it introduced dual banking system which was first of its kind. Indonesian government established Bank Muamalat

column1: ISLAMIC BANKS IN BANGLADESH: The first Islamic bank in Bangladesh was set up in 1983. In fact
